In June 2015, Caitlyn Jenner introduced herself to the world for the first time. She announced her transition at the age of 65 on the cover of Vanity Fair, with a simple cover line: “Call me Caitlyn.” It’s rare to hear trans stories in pop culture in the first place—it’s even more rare at her level. Jenner has since become a symbol for a lot of things, privilege being one of them, but she’s a reminder that it’s never too late to live your truth. “If I was lying on my deathbed and I had kept this secret and never ever did anything about it, I would be lying there saying, ‘You just blew your entire life,’” she told Vanity Fair in the interview accompanying her cover. “‘You never dealt with yourself,’ and I don’t want that to happen.” —B.C.

Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie

Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie gave us an intellectually elegant framework to talk about feminism. Her 2012 Tedx talk, “We Should All Be Feminists,” sampled by Beyoncé in the 2013 hit “Flawless,” did what academics, writers, and politicians have struggled to do for decades: define feminism broadly and inclusively without watering it down. Wildest of all, this wasn’t her biggest success of the decade. She wrote Americanah, a serious contender for great American novel. She capped off the decade by publishing a feminist manifesto, made of suggestions about how to raise a feminist (“Teach her to reject likability” and “Talk to her about sex”) are just two of the great ones. The title of her famous talk was so iconic that Dior put it on a T-shirt. But the talk also contains the line, “We should all be angry. Anger has a long history of bringing about positive change.” Next decade, let’s see that on a T-shirt. —J.S.

Karlie Kloss

In 2015, after three years of working with Victoria’s Secret, Karlie Kloss hung up her Angel wings. It was a surprising move to pass on such a lucrative deal, given that she was one of the brand’s highest-profile models. But, as Kloss later explained, "I didn’t feel it was an image that was truly reflective of who I am and the kind of message I want to send to young women around the world about what it means to be beautiful.” Kloss continues to write her own narrative to positively impact the future, especially in her work with Kode With Klossy. The free coding camp gives young girls the opportunity to learn more about STEM. As Kloss says on the website, "Now, more than ever, women need to have a seat at the table in shaping the technologies that are shaping our world." —T.A.

Lindsay Lohan

If the aughts saw Lindsay Lohan’s star peak on the heels of Freaky Friday and Mean Girls, the ’10s were spent watching it fizzle. While we waited patiently for a comeback from 2007’s Georgia Rule (called “Lindsay Lohan's Gigli”) and box-office bomb I Know Who Killed Me, we were given Machete (I have no recollection of this film) and Liz & Dick. (The nicest review, from the Toronto Sun, called her performance “not the worst thing ever.”) In 2018 she opened a resort in Mykonos and picked up a vaguely European, vaguely Middle Eastern accent; the resort was at the center of her MTV reality show, Lindsay Lohan's Beach Club, which was canceled after one season. Lohan's 2019 was…unspectacular. She was a “guesser” on the first season of the Australian edition of Masked Singer and released “Xanax,” her first new song in 11 years—but only on Instagram TV. That’s the thing about Lohan: After a decade of ups and downs—okay, almost all downs—we continue to root for her. There’s always next decade. —K.F.

Katy Perry

Something incredible happened during Katy Perry’s Super Bowl halftime performance in 2015. When she asked the crowd of more than 60,000 people to complete the lyrics to her song “California Gurls,” they succeeded with flying colors. “I know a place,” Perry sang before turning it over to the massive crowd, who belted in precise unison, “Where the grass is really greener.” The fact that seemingly everyone in the stadium knew the lyrics to “California Gurls” speaks to the song’s ubiquity. It was the first of five number one singles off Perry’s 2010 album, Teenage Dream—a stunning feat accomplished only by Michael Jackson for his 1987 record Bad. That alone earns Perry a spot on our list of the decade’s most influential women, but the singer did more than just break chart records. She was one of the driving forces behind the sound of pop radio in the 2010s, specifically the first five years: glossy, booming, sugary-sweet, and undeniably catchy. A teenage dream indeed. —C.R.

Selena Gomez

Millennials have been called The Anxiety Generation, with nearly 40 million people experiencing an anxiety disorder any given year. While this is obviously not a good stat, it has opened up the dialogue on mental health. Talking about it has become way more normalized, thanks in large part to women like Selena Gomez. The singer and actor has been open about both her mental and physical health, often turning to Instagram to discuss the anxiety and panic attacks she’s been dealing with as a result of managing her lupus. In 2017, after taking a break from the public eye, Gomez revealed that she had a kidney transplant by sharing the news on Instagram. Not only was this exemplary of Gomez’s radical transparency, but it became a meaningful example of the power of female friendship: Her close friend Francia Raisa donated her kidney. —B.C.

Priyanka Chopra

International treasure Priyanka Chopra Jonas is a household name for a few reasons. She's an actor, producer, UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador, Miss World pageant winner, model, and the most famous "J Sister" after her multiday wedding nearly blew up the Internet. She made the transition from Bollywood to Hollywood and broke diversity barriers while she was at it, becoming the first South Asian woman to lead an American series, in ABC’s Quantico. And while some may be uncomfortable with this level of superstardom—with, oh, just about 42 million people watching her every move on Instagram and Twitter—Chopra Jonas navigates it with the kind of grace you'd expect from a seasoned royal (not unlike her actual best friend Meghan Markle). And like a real-life princess, she knows the importance of being a good role model. This year the 37-year-old was awarded Danny Kaye Humanitarian Award for her philanthropic work with UNICEF over the last decade, and for her dedication to children’s rights and education. —S.S.

Kate Middleton

Hard to believe now, but Kate Middleton—or the Duchess of Cambridge, as she’s now known—had an unflattering nickname by the British tabloid press at the start of the decade: Waity Katie. Of course, she would eventually become engaged to Prince William, kicking off a new era of the royal family. Their 2011 wedding was seen around the world with an estimated 72 million live streams on YouTube. Her stunning Alexander McQueen gown—designed by creative director Sarah Burton—also gave way to one of the most iconic partnerships of the decade, with Middleton turning to the designer for major life moments including the christenings of her three children, Prince George, Princess Charlotte, and Prince Louis. Her fashion (rewears!), hair (bouncy blowouts!), and beauty impact (lip gloss mania!) aside, the duchess has carved her own path in the royal family as an advocate for mental health and children’s well-being. We can’t wait to see what she does next. —J.R.

Jennifer Lopez

Those who were surprised by Jennifer Lopez’s stellar performance in the movie Hustlers obviously aren’t familiar with her work. This is a woman who has proved her talent time and time again—particularly over the last decade. As always, Lopez’s contributions to the 2010s spanned medium and genre, from her 2011 dance-club smash “On the Floor” to her critically praised return to television Shades of Blue, and her beloved stint judging American Idol. Throw in a Las Vegas residency, the Hustlers Oscars buzz, and a 2020 Super Bowl halftime performance, and you have one of the decade’s most diverse catalogs. It’s hard to say what Lopez’s specific imprint on the 2010s is. Maybe hers is purposefully, beautifully un-specific—a display in glittering, awe-inspiring showmanship. Whatever the case, Lopez demonstrated, yet again, what an unprecedented, unmatched talent she is. Maybe she’ll finally win an Academy Award for it. —C.R.

Sandra Bullock

Twenty-ten started off rocky for Sandra Bullock: In January she took home a Golden Globe for playing Leigh Anne Tuohy in 2009’s The Blind Side, a role that would earn her the Best Actress Academy Award that March. But just days after walking the Oscars carpet with her husband of four years, Jesse James, the Monster Garage host was moving out of their home amid claims he’d had multiple affairs. Bullock filed for divorce on April 23—and five days later announced she would proceed with plans to adopt a son, Louis. (She and her now ex had started the adoption process months earlier.) She’d close out the year as the world’s highest-paid female actor, a rank she’d earn again in 2014. The following year she started dating photographer Bryan Randall, who was by her side when she adopted daughter Laila in December. Throughout the personal highs and lows, America’s sweetheart worked steadily; four of her highest-grossing films (Minions, Gravity, The Heat, Ocean’s 8) premiered this decade, and she was the standout in 2018’s Bird Box, which saw 26 million views the week it dropped on Netflix. —K.F.

Ellen Pompeo

Grey’s Anatomy has been on our screens for so long that Ellen Pompeo—who stars as the titular character Meredith Grey—could have deserved an inclusion on this list for that reason alone. The show airs in more than 220 countries worldwide and, even 16 seasons in, still commands television audiences. But it was her fight to be equally compensated and her unrelenting calling out of lack of diversity and inequality that’s marked her as one of the most influential, genuinely change-making actors of her generation. She has spoken openly about her frustration that male costar Patrick Dempsey was paid double her salary for the first three seasons of the show, recalling: “At one point, I asked for $5,000 more than him just on principle, because the show is Grey's Anatomy and I'm Meredith Grey. They wouldn't give it to me." She kept fighting, and now is one of the highest-paid stars on television—male or female—with a cool $20 million a year. We tip our hats. —N.P.

Emilia Clarke

Game of Thrones was arguably the biggest TV show of the decade, and Emilia Clarke, Mother of Killer Scenes, arguably its strongest female lead. As Danerys Targarean, Clarke tamed dragons and entire armies of men. She portrayed a rare type of female character: ambitious, ruthless, respected vulnerable, complicated—a woman who showed those who doubted her (cough, men) a leadership that demanded respect. Offscreen, Clarke brought us some of her character’s best traits IRL showing an incredible level of strength and vulnerability when she opened up about the brain aneurysms that almost killed her while she was filming the show. She’s since started a charity to help those suffering after a brain injury or stroke. —M.M.

Kelly Ripa

In 2011, Kelly Ripa said a tearful on-air goodbye to Regis Philbin, her Live! With Regis and Kelly cohost of over 10 years. (During that decade, she was credited with bringing “new life” and a younger audience to the show.) She would spend a year with a rotating lineup of cohosts (Rob Lowe, Kevin Jonas, and Mario Lopez, to name just a few), all while reminding us who the real star was before welcoming Michael Strahan to the gig full-time. When he left in 2016, she again carried the show through a second yearlong rotation of potential cohosts before Ryan Seacrest took over Strahan’s seat permanently in 2017. She may have found a cohost, but it’s Ripa who keeps the ship afloat: The show continues to dominate in audience, with an average of 5 million viewers per episode, as well as ratings in major markets. —K.F.

Teresa Giudice

It all started with a table flip. Teresa Giudice began the 2010s as the breakout star of Real Housewives of New Jersey thanks to one very memorable dinner party that became a nationwide fascination. The success of that moment alone helped make Bravo’s Housewives franchise as a whole become the cultural juggernaut we know and love (or love to hate, depending on your outlook) today. Giudice was also one of the first reality stars to savvily use her fame to help her business ventures, which has included everything from cookbooks to a hair-care line to Bellini cocktails. And, of course, if you’ve read People once, then you know she’s also behind the biggest Housewives scandal of the decade: In 2014, Teresa and her husband, Joe, pleaded guilty to 41 counts of fraud. Teresa served 11 months in federal prison—an experience which, true to form, inspired two New York Times best-selling memoirs. —A.M.

Jameela Jamil

In a time when words like authenticity and unapologetic are so overused they’re starting to lose their meaning, Jameela Jamil is someone who embodies the true essence behind them. The actor and activist is fervent in supporting and uplifting women from all walks of life, advocating for intersectional feminism and body neutrality while fighting against abortion shaming and embracing ones back-fat at all times. From opening up about her battle with an eating disorder to sharing her story on attempted suicide, Jamil is an open book about her own struggles. And while she’s quick to call out brands for “toxic feminism” and unsolicited Photoshop or come for problematic men on Twitter with pointed clap-backs, she’s not afraid to admit her own shortcomings. The actor has spoken to her own “problematic thinking” in the past, and works to combat the toxicity of cancel culture, which is all too real in this day and age. —E.P.

Jennifer Aniston

Let the 2010s henceforth be known as the decade Jennifer Aniston established herself as a pop-culture icon even bigger than Rachel Greene. After years of headlining some of our favorite romantic comedies, Aniston made a culture-shaking return to television with Apple TV+’s The Morning Show, of which she is both a star and producer. The Morning Show parallels so many of the issues that women are battling right now—sexism, ageism, the toxic patriarchal work culture that triggered the #MeToo movement—and Aniston (along with her costar and coproducer Reese Witherspoon) is calling the shots. When you take a step back and consider that Aniston, who turned 50 this year, is even more of a Hollywood icon than she was at the height of her Friends heyday, you begin to get the idea that maybe she, like so many women, hasn’t always gotten her due. But now? She’s in control of her own narrative. —M.M.

Kim Kardashian West

By 2010, when the fifth season of Keep Up With the Kardashians premiered, Kim Kardashian West had graduated from Paris Hilton’s sidekick to a reality star in her own right. And while she’d dedicate plenty of time to the show over the next 10 years, Kim spent much of the decade growing her brand—and her family—outside of it. Her marriage to Kris Humphries began and ended in 2011, but her next relationship with now husband Kanye West would see her through the rest of the decade. The two have welcomed four kids and celebrated five years of marriage in May. She launched her third, fourth, and fifth fragrances, and then KKW Beauty, KKW Fragrance, and the Skims shapewear line, released a book (2015’s Selfish), the Kim Kardashian: Hollywood app (it earned $1.6 million in the first five days), and her best-selling KIMOJI emoji pack. All while keeping her Instagram account consistently at the top of the most-followed list. (She's currently tied with kid sister Kylie and around 17 million followers ahead of Beyoncé.) Her cover of the winter 2014 issue of Paper did, as the cover line commanded, almost break the internet, bringing the site 15.9 million views in a day, compared with its 25,000 daily average. In her spare time, she advocated for prison reform, gun control, and the recognition of the Armenian genocide, all while quietly studying to pass the California bar exam. Keep up, indeed. —K.F.
